Dear Ms. DeVivo:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Repeat noncompliance: The agency must report why the previous CAP
failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency did not follow policy on face to face for the first month of Yes
care using allowable alternatives to verify child's safe sleep
environment and practice.
III. METHODOLOGY

ALLEGATION:
Agency did not follow policy on face to face for the first month of care using
allowable alternatives to verify child's safe sleep environment and practice.
INVESTIGATION:
It is notable that contacts began with the notification of the child's death on 04/02/20
by the Director. Information was later received from Office of Family Advocate (OFA)
2

which prompted the investigation begin opened on 04/08/20. The OFA report noted
that Foster Child A died in the relative placement and DHHS ‘determined that
contrary to court orders, the mother had spent the night in the home, was caring for
the children, and had placed the children in an unsafe sleep situation.’ The report
also noted that the agency had not documented a second face to face visit in the
first month of placement.
I received notification of Foster Child A’s death on 04/02/20 and spoke with the
Director on 04/03/20. The Director reported, and documentation confirmed, that
proper notifications were made per licensing rules. The Director stated that the
relative assessment was completed and the relatives “said all the right things” and
were approved. The Director did identify that the foster care worker did not complete
the two required face to face visits in the first 30 days of placement. This was
apparently missed as the case changed from one foster care worker (no longer
employed with the agency) to the current Worker, coupled with the in-person contact
restrictions due to COVID 19 at the time. Per the Director, Foster Child A was
reportedly just over two months old and was noted to be healthy for a premature
baby who was born exposed to substances. The mother was at the unlicensed
relative home overnight on the night the child died and was not supposed to have
unsupervised visits. The relatives apparently allowed her in the home unbeknownst
to the agency. There is a DHHS Specialist and law enforcement assigned to
investigate the mother on this case, not the agency staff.
I interviewed the Worker on 04/12/20 via phone. The Worker reported that the
previous worker left the agency but had been on emergency leave prior, and not all
documentation was up to date when she got the case. The Worker said that there
was “quite a delay” in scheduling a visit as the relative did not answer her calls for
about a week and she was not able to leave a voice message every time. This
relative does not use text messaging per the Worker. The Worker went on to say
that, on 03/10/20, she set an appointment for a home visit for 03/12/20, but due to
COVID 19 precautions and restrictions on face to face contacts that subsequently
were released, she changed the in-person home visit to a phone call with the
relatives. The Worker stated that she spoke with both relatives during the call and
neither said that the mother was in the home or had been in the home. The Worker
said that when she asked about parental visits with the mother, the relatives stated
that visits are “suspended” due to COVID 19, but they were doing Facetime calls
with the mother and babies. The Worker said she was advised by the relative that
the mother was living with another relative and made it clear she was not there. The
Worker stated that she reviewed with the relatives the visit guidelines as well as safe
sleep. The Worker noted that she had not received a response to her reaching out to
the mother in her time with the case.
MiSACWIS review of relevant case information found the following:
 Child placed in the relative home 02/14/20
 Social work contacts noted:
o Face to face visit by the previous worker on 02/24/20.
3

o Phone only visit/FTM on 03/12/20 by the Worker due to COVID 19.
o Notification received by Worker from law enforcement of Foster Child
A’s death on 04/02/20. The mother was in the relative’s home and told
police she knew she was not supposed to have unsupervised contact.
The relatives also reportedly told the officer they were aware of the
required supervised visits.
APPLICABLE POLICY
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME PLACEMENT
The primary caseworker must have face-to-face contact with
each child as indicated below.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement Change
 The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with each child in the first two months
following an initial placement or a placement change.
 The first face-to-face contact must take place within five
business days of the date of removal or placement
change.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the policy as the worker did not
have an initial face to face contact in the first five business days
of the placement or have two in the first month of placement.
The child was placed in the home on 02/14/20 and the worker
first saw the child on 02/24/20. Another visit was not planned to
occur until 03/12/20. The Director and Worker acknowledged
this. A safety plan was not required as twin to Foster Child A
and the other sibling in the home were moved to another
relative’s home for care and supervision.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report, 09/27/19 and Corresponding
CAP received 10/11/19.
The agency must report why the previous CAP failed and
how they are going to ensure compliance.
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the agency submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
